newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.S. could curb grain exports - Worldwatch chief.
newsitem.headline: U.S. could curb grain exports - Worldwatch chief.

text.p: The United States, one of the world's largest grain producers, could resort to export restrictions if its historically low grain stockpiles threaten domestic food supplies, the Worldwatch Institute's Lester Brown said on Wednesday.

Lester Brown, president of the Washington-based study group, said Vietnam a year ago embargoed rice exports for months because rice in the northern part of the country was being sold to China. And the European Union last September imposed an export tax on wheat to reduce exports and bread prices.
"If Europe can do it, I don't think one could rule out the United States," he told reporters in Tokyo.
Brown is visiting Japan this week to give lectures on world food security.

World grain stocks are hovering at a 20-year low following droughts in major grain producing areas such as Australia and North America. Droughts last year damaged grain production in the United States and pushed down its grain stockpiles to historically low levels.
The U.S. government suspended soybean exports to Japan in the 1970s because of supply shortages and rising food prices there.
Officials at Japan's Agriculture Ministry say they are carefully watching low grain stocks in the United States and grain export policy.
"We don't want to think the U.S. government will resort to a grain export embargo. But we still remember the soybean export embargo in 1970s," a senior ministry official said.
